answer_html: \(\int \cos^{2}(x) \, dx=\frac{x}{2}+ \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + C\) completing the question.

question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
First we use the double angle formula

\(\cos^{2}(x) = \frac{1+\cos(2x)}{2}\)

to see that

\[\begin{aligned} \int \cos^{2}(x) \, dx &= \int \frac{1+\cos(2x)}{2} \, dx \\ &= \frac{x}{2} + \frac{1}{2}\int \cos(2x) \, dx \\ &= \frac{x}{2}+ \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + C\end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_latex:
First we use the double angle formula

$\cos^{2}(x) = \frac{1+\cos(2x)}{2}$

to see that

\begin{align*}
\int \cos^{2}(x) \, dx  &= \int \frac{1+\cos(2x)}{2} \, dx \\
&= \frac{x}{2}  +  \frac{1}{2}\int \cos(2x) \, dx \\
&=  \frac{x}{2}+  \frac{1}{4} \sin(2x) + C
\end{align*}

completing the question.
